cards.front: What is the Fourier Transform analysis integral?
cards.back: X(jω) = ∫_{-∞}^{∞} x(t) e^{-jωt} dt — correlates x(t) with complex exponentials at every frequency

cards.front: What is the inverse Fourier Transform?
cards.back: x(t) = (1/2π) ∫_{-∞}^{∞} X(jω) e^{jωt} dω — reconstructs x(t) from its spectrum
1/(a + jω) for a > 0 — a Lorentzian (lowpass) spectrum with magnitude 1/√(a² + ω²)
τ sinc(ωτ/2π) — a sinc function whose first null is at ω = 2π/τ
e^{-jωt₀} X(jω) — delay adds linear phase, magnitude unchanged
X(j(ω - ω₀)) — spectrum shifts right by ω₀ (modulation/AM)
jω X(jω) — differentiation = multiplication by jω in frequency

cards.front: What is conjugate symmetry for real signals?
cards.back: X*(jω) = X(-jω) — magnitude is even, phase is odd for real x(t)
X(jω)·H(jω) — convolution in time = multiplication in frequency
